titleStmt.title: Letter from Thomas W. Knox to Samuel L. Clemens : an electronic text

sourceDesc.bibl: MS, Mark Twain Papers, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley (CU-MARK).

body.head:
Thomas W. Knox to Samuel L. Clemens
31 March 1884 • New York, New York (MS: CU-MARK, UCLC 41962)

div1.p: The King of Siam writes meKnox had possibly met the King of Siam, who recently conferred upon him, through a letter from the Counsul at Bangkok, the honor of a knighthood in the Order of the White Elephant in thanks for his service to Siam (“A White Elephant Knight,” Washington D. C. Morning Star, 22 Mar 1881, 1). Knox's service consisted mainly of his positive depiction of Siam in The Boy Travelers in Siam and Java (1882). Chulalongkorn (1853-1910) was the fifth King of Siam of the Chakri Dynasty, who ruled from 1868 to his death in 1910. He is credited with promoting significant social and political reforms, as well as with keeping western expansionist powers at bay. that his children—some 258 at last accountsAt the time of this letter the King had produced some 45 children by nearly as many consorts. See the wikipedia compilation at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_children_of_Chulalongkorn.—are crying for playthings, & the din is terrible. He thinks your autograph would silence them & I beg you’ll send it along, one for each. Better make it an even three hundred as the family is likely to increase.

If you have any left over after filling
this royal commission please send one to me. I want it well done & rare, turned over & browned, stem-winding & with gilt sides & edges.This nonsensical list of specifications was possibly a play on the sorts of prescriptions for paper type, ink, etc. found in letter-writing manuals. It’s for a sick lady.Compare to R. U. Johnson's appeal for "a lame boy."
